text: [3.2 | Candlelight Dinner: Red Dress and Good Food]
Night falls quickly, and the snow buries the sounds of the street.
I hang the “Closed” sign earlier than usual. The dull thud of the bolt sliding into place sounds like sealing the entire town outside.
Then I return to the kitchen—driven by some unreasonable impulse—and start cooking.

A pot of stew simmers over low heat, its aroma slowly filling the hallway. The crust of the bread cracks in the oven, oil and salt rising into the air. I slice cured meat and cheese, and wipe down the last bottle of wine that isn’t too sour, placing it at the center of the table.
I tell myself: it’s just a meal. Just… a way to make tonight less terrible than usual.
Footsteps sound on the stairs.
First step. Second step. Third step—she pauses.
My heart feels like someone has lightly plucked it with a fingertip. I haven’t looked up, yet I already know she’s coming down.
Alicia steps into the firelight.
She wears no cloak. No armor.

A long red dress falls against her figure, cutting a line through the night that’s almost too bright. The red is too vivid, too clean—like a flower blooming in the snow. Beautiful, unreasonable, out of place.
Her silver hair is loosely pinned up, a few strands falling along her neck. In the firelight, they gleam like scattered blades.
“You…”
I meant to say, “Why are you dressed like that?” But the words catch in my throat, like I’m afraid of breaking something.
“Do I look good?”
She asks softly—half testing, half commanding.
“…You’re very conspicuous.”
“That’s the point.”
She walks to the table, her fingertips brushing the edge of the tablecloth, as if confirming this isn’t an illusion.
Then she notices the spread of food. Her gaze goes briefly blank—not shock, but something like being struck by hesitation.
“You really did it.”
“I said I would.”
I ladle the stew and place it in front of her. Steam rises, softening her face for a moment.
She sits very straight, steady, like she could draw an invisible sword from the chair at any moment.
But her fingers lightly rub the edge of the table, as if holding back an unnecessary tremor.
“You closed the tavern.”
“Yeah. No customers tonight.”
I pour the wine. The liquid taps softly against the glass.
She watches the cup, and suddenly her expression twists into something that’s almost a smile, but not quite.
“Did you know? Every time you pour wine, you spill just a little.”
My hand jerks. A drop spills over.
“…Not every time.”
“Yes. Every time.”
She says it with absolute certainty, like she’s stating a pattern already proven by data.
I wipe the rim of the glass and deliberately avoid her eyes.
We start eating.
The stew is hot. The bread smells good. The cured meat is a bit salty. Normal—too normal for a dinner that shouldn’t exist in a story like this.
But whenever the fire pops, her gaze flickers. Whenever the wind outside grows louder, her fingertip taps the table once, like she’s counting.
I try to talk about light things: the baker in town, the child selling flowers by the fountain, the snow these past few days.
She responds—more than she did during the day—as if she’s suddenly decided to pry some long-held silence apart by force.
“I never used to wear red.”
“Why not?”
“Because red looks like blood.”
Then she adds, her tone light enough to sound like a lie:
“But tonight, I want you to remember me.”
My chopsticks freeze halfway. My throat goes dry.
She takes a sip of wine, her eyes drifting instead to the fading bruise on the back of my hand.
“Does it hurt?”
“Not anymore.”
She studies me, like she’s calculating the probability that I’m lying.
“I’ll remove everything that hurts you.”
The statement is too direct—direct enough to make my spine go cold.
But after saying it, she lowers her head and drinks her soup, as if she were just commenting on the weather.
The meal slowly draws to an end.
Firelight throws the shadow of her red dress onto the wall. The shadow is bolder than she is, like a banner.
I suddenly realize: she didn’t come here for a “date.” She’s using this meal to drag some ending forward—pulling it into a rhythm she can control.
And me—I actually cooked a good meal, closed the tavern early, and locked myself into her rhythm with her.
She sets her cup down and taps the glass once with her fingertip.
“We’re done eating.”
“Now it’s your turn to listen.”
She looks up. Her gray-blue eyes shine too brightly in the firelight, like she’s about to pin me in place.
